claim: Parents share more genes with their child than siblings do.

supporting.text: Parents pass on exactly 50% of their genes to each child, while siblings share on average 50% of their genes due to random recombination, making parents and children equally related genetically.

attacks.text: Parents pass on exactly 50% of their genes to each child, while siblings share on average 50% of their genes due to random recombination, making parents and children equally related genetically.
The 50% shared between siblings is an average; some sibling pairs share significantly more or less than 50% due to random assortment of genes during meiosis.
Parents share 50% of their genes with each child, but siblings can share up to 100% if they are identical twins, which is a higher genetic similarity than parent-child relationships.

Mitochondrial DNA is inherited exclusively from the mother, meaning children share 100% of their mitochondrial DNA with their mother, which is not the case for siblings unless they are identical twins.
While sibling genetic sharing can vary, the average remains 50%, which is the same as parent-child sharing, so the original claim of equal relatedness holds in most cases.
Identical twins are a rare exception and do not represent the general case of sibling genetic sharing, so they should not be used to argue against the average 50% sharing.
Mitochondrial DNA represents a very small fraction of the total genome, so its exclusive inheritance does not significantly alter the overall 50% genetic sharing between parents and children.
Even if the average is 50%, the variability in sibling genetic sharing means that in many cases, siblings are less genetically similar than parents and children, supporting the original claim.
The rarity of identical twins does not negate the fact that they exist and can share more genes than parent-child pairs, which is a valid counterpoint to the general claim.

supporting.text: Mutations or de novo genetic variations in a child are inherited solely from the parents, not siblings, which can make the parent-child genetic relationship slightly more direct in some cases.

attacks.text: Mutations or de novo genetic variations in a child are inherited solely from the parents, not siblings, which can make the parent-child genetic relationship slightly more direct in some cases.
De novo mutations are rare, so their impact on the overall genetic similarity between parents and children is negligible compared to the shared genetic material between siblings.
Siblings share a more consistent proportion of genes (around 50%) due to Mendelian inheritance, whereas parent-child genetic similarity can vary more due to recombination and mutations.
Even if de novo mutations are rare, their presence still introduces unique genetic material that is exclusive to the parent-child relationship, not found in siblings.
The 50% genetic similarity between siblings is an average; actual shared DNA can vary significantly due to random assortment, making parent-child relationships more reliably direct.

The uniqueness introduced by de novo mutations is statistically insignificant compared to the vast majority of shared genes, which are identical by descent in both parent-child and sibling relationships.
While parent-child relationships are direct, the genetic recombination process ensures siblings share a mix of both parents' genes, often leading to a more balanced genetic similarity.

supporting.text: Siblings can share more than 50% of their genes if they inherit identical segments from both parents, making them sometimes more genetically similar than parent-child pairs.

attacks.text: Siblings can share more than 50% of their genes if they inherit identical segments from both parents, making them sometimes more genetically similar than parent-child pairs.
Parent-child pairs always share exactly 50% of their genes, while sibling genetic similarity varies, making parent-child similarity more consistent and predictable.
The probability of siblings sharing more than 50% of their genes is statistically low, making parent-child relationships more reliably genetically similar.
Parent-child relationships involve direct genetic transmission, whereas sibling similarity depends on random recombination, making parent-child genetic sharing more fundamental.
Even if sibling genetic similarity varies, the average genetic similarity between siblings is still 50%, the same as parent-child pairs, negating the claim of greater similarity.
Statistical rarity does not disprove the possibility; siblings can and do sometimes share more genes than parent-child pairs, which is the core of the original argument.
Direct genetic transmission does not imply greater similarity; the randomness in sibling gene combination can still result in higher similarity in specific cases.
The average genetic similarity being equal does not address the original point about cases where siblings exceed the 50% threshold, which remains valid.
Focusing on statistical rarity shifts the argument away from the biological possibility, which was the original claim's focus.

supporting.text: Mitochondrial DNA (and Y-chromosome in males) is passed entirely from mother to child, creating a 100% match in those specific genomic regions, unlike sibling relationships.

attacks.text: Mitochondrial DNA (and Y-chromosome in males) is passed entirely from mother to child, creating a 100% match in those specific genomic regions, unlike sibling relationships.
Nuclear DNA, which constitutes the majority of the genome, is shared equally (50%) between parents and children, just like between siblings, making the overall genetic similarity comparable.
Mitochondrial DNA and Y-chromosome represent a very small fraction of the total genome, so their 100% match does not significantly increase the overall genetic similarity between parent and child.

Even though nuclear DNA is shared equally, the combination of nuclear DNA with 100% matched mitochondrial/Y-chromosome DNA still results in a higher total genetic similarity between parent and child than between siblings.
The functional importance of mitochondrial DNA in energy production means that its 100% match has a disproportionately large impact on phenotypic similarity, beyond its small genomic size.
The phenotypic impact of mitochondrial DNA is limited to specific cellular functions and does not affect most observable traits, making its contribution to overall similarity negligible.

supporting.text: Imprinting genes show parent-of-origin effects, meaning certain genes are only active when inherited from one parent, creating unique parent-child genetic interactions not replicated in siblings.

attacks.text: Imprinting genes show parent-of-origin effects, meaning certain genes are only active when inherited from one parent, creating unique parent-child genetic interactions not replicated in siblings.
Imprinting genes are relatively rare in the genome, so their impact on overall genetic similarity between parents and children is minimal compared to the bulk of shared genes.
Siblings can also inherit the same imprinted genes from their parents, meaning the uniqueness of parent-child interactions is not absolute.
Environmental and epigenetic factors can modify the expression of imprinted genes, reducing the deterministic role of parent-of-origin effects.
Even if imprinting genes are rare, their functional impact can be significant, influencing traits like growth and behavior disproportionately.
While siblings may inherit the same imprinted genes, the parent-child interaction is still unique in terms of gene activation patterns.
Epigenetic modifications themselves can be inherited, meaning parent-of-origin effects can persist across generations despite environmental influences.
The functional significance of imprinting genes does not necessarily translate to a greater overall genetic similarity between parents and children.
Gene activation patterns are not solely determined by parent-of-origin effects; other regulatory mechanisms play a significant role.
